explanation_composer.regulatory_rule_cue:
Traffic Separation Scheme (TSS) routing requirement; applies to cargo vessels navigating in designated separation zones; spatial anchor: unnamed traffic separation scheme
Operational Protocol Rationale: The vessel is a cargo ship operating under way with engine, transiting a structured maritime zone marked by a traffic separation scheme. In such areas, vessels are expected to follow predefined curved or straight routes to maintain safe separation from opposing traffic flows. The observed behavior—stable speed, minimal heading variation, and gradual course adjustment—aligns with standard navigation practices within guided waterways, where autopilot systems maintain consistent motion along gently curving channels. This pattern is typical for mid-sized cargo vessels of similar dimensions and draught, which commonly adhere to regulated paths to avoid collision and comply with international maritime routing protocols. Although slight curvature is present, the motion remains sufficiently linear over short segments, making constant-velocity interpolation appropriate. Alternative behaviors involving sharp turns or erratic headings are inconsistent with both the vessel’s operational status and the constraints of the traffic separation environment.
